body:
> Dukkha – discomfort, stress, discontent  –  obviously arises when we encounter experiences that cause us suffering, like physical pain, illness, loss, trauma, not getting what one wants, old age and dying. But it also arises when we experience happiness, joy, boredom, enthusiasm and whole host of other things. Even the most positive, rewarding and enjoyable experience is at least slightly colored by the fact that it will end, or by the fact that at the same moment innocent people are in the midst of terrible suffering. Most of us experience at least a low-grade dukkha all the time. It is like a mild depression we don’t notice until we come out of it, or an ache we have gotten used to. The vague sense that things are not quite as they should be pervades everything.

> Why do we feel the subtlest kind of dukkha, even when everything is going great for us? Underneath all of our more blatant resistance to difficulty and pain, the problem is basically this: we want things to rely on, but all things are impermanent and empty of any inherent, independent, enduring self. Including us. We may not even understand what is bothering us, but the intuition that absolutely everything is impermanent is unnerving.

> Every mobile creature on the planet, from an amoeba on up, moves away from things that cause it harm or pain, and toward things that protect and nourish it. This is how separate units of life survive, reproduce and evolve. The desire to look after ourselves is extremely powerful, especially in a creature like us that has a strong memory of its past and the ability to imagine its future. But the amoeba doesn’t care that all things are impermanent and empty; it just goes on about its business of self-preservation and promotion without a conscious sense of self. Human beings, on the other hand, identify our bodies, sensations, perceptions, thoughts and consciousness as “self.” As one moment flows into the next we have a sense of continuity that we assume is the enduring part of who we are.

> The assumption that there is an enduring part of who we are is wrong. In reality we are only flow. Our self is a composite of materials, processes and emergent phenomena that produces a sensation of an inherent, independent, enduring self. This sensation is extremely adaptive, but in a very intelligent animal it can produce a side-effect of existential angst. What does such an animal do when it suspects it actually has no definable boundaries and is only flow? What does it protect and promote? What can it rely on safety and refuge?

> To the sages of the Buddha’s time there appeared to be only two responses to dukkha:

> * Keep trying to change conditions so we won't feel resistance to them, and ultimately find something permanent to rely on
> * Live with dukkha

> The Buddha realized everything was impermanent and empty of an inherent self, so he knew #1 was not an option. He refused to accept #2. Fortunately, he saw a third option:

> * Let go of the resistance to things as they are, and of the search for something permanent to rely on

https://brightwayzen.org/not-misunderstanding-dukkha/
body_html:
Dukkha – discomfort, stress, discontent – obviously arises when we encounter experiences that cause us suffering, like physical pain, illness, loss, trauma, not getting what one wants, old age and dying. But it also arises when we experience happiness, joy, boredom, enthusiasm and whole host of other things. Even the most positive, rewarding and enjoyable experience is at least slightly colored by the fact that it will end, or by the fact that at the same moment innocent people are in the midst of terrible suffering. Most of us experience at least a low-grade dukkha all the time. It is like a mild depression we don’t notice until we come out of it, or an ache we have gotten used to. The vague sense that things are not quite as they should be pervades everything.

Why do we feel the subtlest kind of dukkha, even when everything is going great for us? Underneath all of our more blatant resistance to difficulty and pain, the problem is basically this: we want things to rely on, but all things are impermanent and empty of any inherent, independent, enduring self. Including us. We may not even understand what is bothering us, but the intuition that absolutely everything is impermanent is unnerving.

Every mobile creature on the planet, from an amoeba on up, moves away from things that cause it harm or pain, and toward things that protect and nourish it. This is how separate units of life survive, reproduce and evolve. The desire to look after ourselves is extremely powerful, especially in a creature like us that has a strong memory of its past and the ability to imagine its future. But the amoeba doesn’t care that all things are impermanent and empty; it just goes on about its business of self-preservation and promotion without a conscious sense of self. Human beings, on the other hand, identify our bodies, sensations, perceptions, thoughts and consciousness as “self.” As one moment flows into the next we have a sense of continuity that we assume is the enduring part of who we are.

The assumption that there is an enduring part of who we are is wrong. In reality we are only flow. Our self is a composite of materials, processes and emergent phenomena that produces a sensation of an inherent, independent, enduring self. This sensation is extremely adaptive, but in a very intelligent animal it can produce a side-effect of existential angst. What does such an animal do when it suspects it actually has no definable boundaries and is only flow? What does it protect and promote? What can it rely on safety and refuge?

To the sages of the Buddha’s time there appeared to be only two responses to dukkha:

  • Keep trying to change conditions so we won't feel resistance to them, and ultimately find something permanent to rely on
  • Live with dukkha

The Buddha realized everything was impermanent and empty of an inherent self, so he knew #1 was not an option. He refused to accept #2. Fortunately, he saw a third option:

  • Let go of the resistance to things as they are, and of the search for something permanent to rely on

https://brightwayzen.org/not-misunderstanding-dukkha/

body:
>Yes, people have almost no say in their lives and nearly everything is determined for them, and no, it's not a good thing.

The truth is in the middle, man.

I have control over lots of things in my life. Various decisions I've made have shaped my life into something that could otherwise have been completely different.

I also have no control over lots of things in my life. I can't change my genes or the circumstances of my birth.

You have to acknowledge both these facts and make the best of things that you can.

Life can be absolutely awful and it can also be pretty fucking great.

body:
> The world is what you make of it. Give love to others and you will receive love in exchange. Work hard and apply yourself and you will succeed.

That's the first lie. 90% of your life is what you're born with. And another 9% comes from external factors you can't control. You can only choose about 1% of what you will ever experience. And yes, the other 99% gives some people more of what they want than others. Some people just have an innate ability to do everything right all the time with no thought, and others can't get the hang of anything no matter how hard they try. Some people have skills that don't match their interests. Some people look better than others. Some people are naturally more charismatic and seen as better than others. Not everyone can do everything, but only what they've been given. And it is just random what you end up with, not fair.

body:
I don't think it's very quantifiable. But of course I have a lot of control. 

Today, I can work on my novel, which I'm writing specifically to appeal to a broad audience so it will sell.

Or I can apply for a bunch of traditional hourly work with an eye toward getting a steady income to supplement my wife and girlfriends' income.

Or I can work out and journal all my calories and try to improve my health and appearance.

Or I can go to a bar, get drunk, and try to make a new friendship.

Or I can go help my nearly-homeless buddy get moved into the new room he's semi-scammed his way into.

Or I can lock myself in the basement and jerk off to Brazilian women pissing on each others' faces.

I have many choices, and every choice I make will have consequences down the road. I'm not just a gallstone being pushed through the bile ducts of life.

body:
Obviously we're not going to solve the centuries-old nature versus nurture debate on a quick Ruqqus thread. There are millions of pages written in support of either argument, and no clear victor has ever emerged.

Which is why I think the sanest assumption to make is that the answer is in the middle.

Yes, planning and hard work can pay off. Yes, planning and hard work can completely fall apart and leave you with nothing. That's just reality, and we have little choice but to accept it.

parent.body:
> Dukkha – discomfort, stress, discontent  –  obviously arises when we encounter experiences that cause us suffering, like physical pain, illness, loss, trauma, not getting what one wants, old age and dying. But it also arises when we experience happiness, joy, boredom, enthusiasm and whole host of other things. Even the most positive, rewarding and enjoyable experience is at least slightly colored by the fact that it will end, or by the fact that at the same moment innocent people are in the midst of terrible suffering. Most of us experience at least a low-grade dukkha all the time. It is like a mild depression we don’t notice until we come out of it, or an ache we have gotten used to. The vague sense that things are not quite as they should be pervades everything.

> Why do we feel the subtlest kind of dukkha, even when everything is going great for us? Underneath all of our more blatant resistance to difficulty and pain, the problem is basically this: we want things to rely on, but all things are impermanent and empty of any inherent, independent, enduring self. Including us. We may not even understand what is bothering us, but the intuition that absolutely everything is impermanent is unnerving.

> Every mobile creature on the planet, from an amoeba on up, moves away from things that cause it harm or pain, and toward things that protect and nourish it. This is how separate units of life survive, reproduce and evolve. The desire to look after ourselves is extremely powerful, especially in a creature like us that has a strong memory of its past and the ability to imagine its future. But the amoeba doesn’t care that all things are impermanent and empty; it just goes on about its business of self-preservation and promotion without a conscious sense of self. Human beings, on the other hand, identify our bodies, sensations, perceptions, thoughts and consciousness as “self.” As one moment flows into the next we have a sense of continuity that we assume is the enduring part of who we are.

> The assumption that there is an enduring part of who we are is wrong. In reality we are only flow. Our self is a composite of materials, processes and emergent phenomena that produces a sensation of an inherent, independent, enduring self. This sensation is extremely adaptive, but in a very intelligent animal it can produce a side-effect of existential angst. What does such an animal do when it suspects it actually has no definable boundaries and is only flow? What does it protect and promote? What can it rely on safety and refuge?

> To the sages of the Buddha’s time there appeared to be only two responses to dukkha:

> * Keep trying to change conditions so we won't feel resistance to them, and ultimately find something permanent to rely on
> * Live with dukkha

> The Buddha realized everything was impermanent and empty of an inherent self, so he knew #1 was not an option. He refused to accept #2. Fortunately, he saw a third option:

> * Let go of the resistance to things as they are, and of the search for something permanent to rely on

https://brightwayzen.org/not-misunderstanding-dukkha/
parent.body_html:
Dukkha – discomfort, stress, discontent – obviously arises when we encounter experiences that cause us suffering, like physical pain, illness, loss, trauma, not getting what one wants, old age and dying. But it also arises when we experience happiness, joy, boredom, enthusiasm and whole host of other things. Even the most positive, rewarding and enjoyable experience is at least slightly colored by the fact that it will end, or by the fact that at the same moment innocent people are in the midst of terrible suffering. Most of us experience at least a low-grade dukkha all the time. It is like a mild depression we don’t notice until we come out of it, or an ache we have gotten used to. The vague sense that things are not quite as they should be pervades everything.

Why do we feel the subtlest kind of dukkha, even when everything is going great for us? Underneath all of our more blatant resistance to difficulty and pain, the problem is basically this: we want things to rely on, but all things are impermanent and empty of any inherent, independent, enduring self. Including us. We may not even understand what is bothering us, but the intuition that absolutely everything is impermanent is unnerving.

Every mobile creature on the planet, from an amoeba on up, moves away from things that cause it harm or pain, and toward things that protect and nourish it. This is how separate units of life survive, reproduce and evolve. The desire to look after ourselves is extremely powerful, especially in a creature like us that has a strong memory of its past and the ability to imagine its future. But the amoeba doesn’t care that all things are impermanent and empty; it just goes on about its business of self-preservation and promotion without a conscious sense of self. Human beings, on the other hand, identify our bodies, sensations, perceptions, thoughts and consciousness as “self.” As one moment flows into the next we have a sense of continuity that we assume is the enduring part of who we are.

The assumption that there is an enduring part of who we are is wrong. In reality we are only flow. Our self is a composite of materials, processes and emergent phenomena that produces a sensation of an inherent, independent, enduring self. This sensation is extremely adaptive, but in a very intelligent animal it can produce a side-effect of existential angst. What does such an animal do when it suspects it actually has no definable boundaries and is only flow? What does it protect and promote? What can it rely on safety and refuge?

To the sages of the Buddha’s time there appeared to be only two responses to dukkha:

  • Keep trying to change conditions so we won't feel resistance to them, and ultimately find something permanent to rely on
  • Live with dukkha

The Buddha realized everything was impermanent and empty of an inherent self, so he knew #1 was not an option. He refused to accept #2. Fortunately, he saw a third option:

  • Let go of the resistance to things as they are, and of the search for something permanent to rely on

https://brightwayzen.org/not-misunderstanding-dukkha/

parent.body:
Obviously we're not going to solve the centuries-old nature versus nurture debate on a quick Ruqqus thread. There are millions of pages written in support of either argument, and no clear victor has ever emerged.

Which is why I think the sanest assumption to make is that the answer is in the middle.

Yes, planning and hard work can pay off. Yes, planning and hard work can completely fall apart and leave you with nothing. That's just reality, and we have little choice but to accept it.

body:
@CrystalVulpine
You didn’t respond to my question and it’s buried so I’m posting it here.

Have you ever experienced agonizing pain? 

I’m talking about the kind of pain that has you writhing on the floor for hours and begging mercy from spiritual figures you aren’t even sure you believe in.

While I wouldn’t wish that on anyone, it’s the kind of thing that changes how you see the world. 

It makes you appreciate the everyday things you take for granted. Like living without terrible pain. Having energy and moving with ease. It makes you feel grateful for feeling “normal” again because it feels so much better than being in pain.

It doesn’t matter what you’ve decided your perspective has to be “biologically”. There are always experiences that can change you.

All it takes is something much worse happening for you to see how good you had it.

body:
> This doesn’t matter even if you are though. Usually people don’t choose to be in pain.

I'd pass out or die from shock or if it went on longer than like 10 minutes probably kill myself, even if it were only like 1/10th the intensity. I just can't handle it, because I'm a worthless sack of shit who can't do anything right.

> Maybe this is something you can be grateful for though - being able to live pain-free.

I can't, again because I just can't change my thinking like that. I am a born pessimist and selfish bag of horse shit. I used to be a little bit more grateful but not a lot, and then after puberty hit I just can't tolerate even the slightest discomfort anymore, and my empathy is limited. I hate it and I would go back if I could, but my mind is locked this way and no matter how hard I've fought it I just fall back on it because it's my nature. Even if I'm determined to change, in the moment I just can't and always do the same thing. It's nature.

body:
You can't just "change them at will," but you can adjust your expectations.

Like, you know, I had a friend whose lifelong dream was to be a famous director like Spielberg or Cameron or Fincher.

He couldn't cut it. He didn't have the chops. He failed. And he was depressed bordering on suicidal.

But eventually he found that being a sound editor for films *was* something he had the chops for, and... it pays well and he has a nice life.

body: The reason I know I can't ever fix it is because it's been shown to be rooted in brain structure. I am pessimistic, selfish, can't tolerate the slightest discomfort, unproductive, unintelligent, uncreative, untalented, constantly depressed and angry, forgetful, etc. and that's all down to biology just as much as height and speed are. No matter how hard I try to rebel against this I always fall back and end up doing the same things anyway and nothing ever changes. All resistance is futile, nurture never overcomes nature. And it wasn't quite as bad before I hit puberty and my brain was more malleable, so that's another reason I know it's probably uncontrollable. And I bet I'll have to be this way for the rest of my life, just a miserable worthless piece of flesh who does nothing but take up space and be a nuisance to the people who are actually worth something.

body:
Or just become more used to it.

I don't think you understand just how bad I am. It can't be only depression, because that is *caused* by many of these other things. I'm sick of not being able to do anything or even take anything slightly hard. Even in this thread alone people have done the impossible (for me). And a few people I've encountered in the past year can do literally anything, without a single fault, with very little experience, perfectly, and with little thought or effort, and they know literally every single tiny detail about everything in the universe, almost automatically. And a few of them have almost everything else going for them too, even the most minor details of life. It drives me insane and makes me wonder if some of them might even be fake people sent to test how we react to them or something.

And on top of that I'm selfish and pessimistic and unthankful and uncaring and a miserable wretch who just takes up space. Can't change that either, you can see I hate it, being so rotten like this, but when it comes to acting differently I simply can't do it. It's in my nature to be this way, that I can tell. Can't even change my thinking, it's how I'm wired.

parent.body_html: You imply it every time you insist there’s nothing you can do.

post.body:
There are two main ways people try to get around this fact. One group of people says that you create your own luck, your own destiny, etc., you choose to be happy or unhappy, everything is by perseverance, genes don't mean anything, etc. Basically they insist that the world is fair and the choice is yours. The other group acknowledges that we are unfairly divided by biology, external circumstances, etc. but they somehow manage to glorify it, saying that is how it *should* be. The first position is a lie. The second one is evil.

This is obviously mental gymnastics to stop us from admitting the truth. Yes, people have almost no say in their lives and nearly everything is determined for them, and no, it's not a good thing. And no, there's nothing we can do about it. It's the truth, and we're not getting anywhere by trying to get around it. You get what you are handed, and that's the end of it. It's the red/black pill.

Edit: seeing as my post was yanked to +IncelTears, no this isn't an incel problem. I mean incel problems are one thing this encompasses, but I'm not an incel nor was it the point of this post.
